query: Who wrote Alice's Adventures in Wonderland?
expected_answer: The author of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" is Lewis Carroll.
citations:
["Title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland

Author: Lewis Carroll

Release date: June 27, 2008 [eBook #11]
                Most recently updated: June 26, 2025"]

query: When was the eBook of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland released and last updated?
expected_answer: The eBook was released on June 27, 2008, and most recently updated on June 26, 2025.
citations: ['Release date: June 27, 2008 [eBook #11]\n                Most recently updated: June 26, 2025']

query: What was Alice doing at the beginning of Chapter 1?
expected_answer: Alice was sitting by her sister on the bank, feeling tired and bored because her sister's book had no pictures or conversations.
citations:
['CHAPTER I.
Down the Rabbit-Hole


Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the
bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into
the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or
conversations in it, “and what is the use of a book,” thought Alice
“without pictures or conversations?”']

query: What animal did Alice see suddenly?
expected_answer: Alice saw a White Rabbit with pink eyes run close by her.
citations:
['So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the
hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of
making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and
picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran
close by her.']

query: What was written on the jar Alice found while falling?
expected_answer: Alice found a jar labeled "ORANGE MARMALADE" in the rabbit-hole, but it was empty.
citations:
['She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she
passed; it was labelled “ORANGE MARMALADE”, but to her great
disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear
of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the
cupboards as she fell past it.']

query: Who is Dinah?
expected_answer: Dinah is Alice's cat.
citations: ['“Dinah’ll miss me very much to-night, I should think!”\n(Dinah was the cat.)']

query: How tall was the little door Alice found?
expected_answer: Alice found a little door about fifteen inches high behind a low curtain.
citations:
['However, on the second
time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and
behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the
little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!']

query: What did the liquid in the bottle taste like?
expected_answer: The drink from the bottle tasted like a mix of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast.
citations:
['However, this bottle was _not_ marked “poison,” so Alice ventured to
taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed
flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and
hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.']

query: What was Alice's height after drinking from the bottle?
expected_answer: After drinking from the bottle, Alice shrank to ten inches high.
citations: ['And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face\nbrightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going\nthrough the little door into that lovely garden.']

query: What did Alice find under the table?
expected_answer: Alice found a small cake with the words "EAT ME" marked in currants.
citations: ['Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table:\nshe opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words\n“EAT ME” were beautifully marked in currants.']

query: How tall did Alice become after eating the cake?
expected_answer: Alice grew to be more than nine feet high.
citations: ['Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was\nnow more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden\nkey and hurried off to the garden door.']

query: How deep was the pool of tears Alice created?
expected_answer: Alice's tears formed a pool about four inches deep, reaching half down the hall.
citations: ['But she went on all the same, shedding\ngallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about\nfour inches deep and reaching half down the hall.']

query: What was the White Rabbit carrying when he returned?
expected_answer: The White Rabbit was splendidly dressed, carrying white kid gloves and a large fan.
citations:
['It was the White
Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves
in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a
great hurry, muttering to himself as he came, “Oh! the Duchess, the
Duchess! Oh! won’t she be savage if I’ve kept her waiting!”']

query: What poem did Alice try to recite?
expected_answer: Alice tried to recite "How doth the little crocodile."
citations:
['“How doth the little crocodile
    Improve his shining tail,
And pour the waters of the Nile
    On every golden scale!

“How cheerfully he seems to grin,
    How neatly spread his claws,
And welcome little fishes in
    With gently smiling jaws!”']

query: What caused Alice to shrink again?
expected_answer: Alice realized she was shrinking because of the fan she was holding.
citations:
['She got up and went to the table to measure
herself by it, and found that, as nearly as she could guess, she was
now about two feet high, and was going on shrinking rapidly: she soon
found out that the cause of this was the fan she was holding, and she
dropped it hastily, just in time to avoid shrinking away altogether.']

query: Where did Alice find herself after slipping?
expected_answer: Alice realized she was in the pool of tears she had wept earlier.
citations: ['However, she\nsoon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when\nshe was nine feet high.']

query: What creature did Alice see in the pool of tears?
expected_answer: Alice saw a mouse in the pool of tears.
citations:
['at first she thought
it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small
she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had
slipped in like herself.']

query: What French phrase did Alice say to the Mouse?
expected_answer: Alice tried speaking French, saying "Où est ma chatte?"
citations: ['“Où est ma chatte?” which\nwas the first sentence in her French lesson-book.']

query: What animals were in the pool with Alice?
expected_answer: The pool became crowded with a Duck, a Dodo, a Lory, an Eaglet, and other creatures.
citations: ['It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the\nbirds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a\nDodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures.']

query: How does a Caucus-race work?
expected_answer: In a Caucus-race, participants run in a circle, starting and stopping when they like, until the Dodo declares the race over and everyone wins.
citations:
['“Why,” said the Dodo, “the best way to explain it is to do it.” (And,
as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will
tell you how the Dodo managed it.)

First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact
shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed
along the course, here and there. There was no “One, two, three, and
away,” but they began running when they liked, and left off when they
liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over. However,
when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry
again, the Dodo suddenly called out “The race is over!” and they all
crowded round it, panting, and asking, “But who has won?”']

query: What did Alice give as prizes after the Caucus-race?
expected_answer: Alice gave out comfits as prizes.
citations:
['Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her
pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had
not got into it), and handed them round as prizes. There was exactly
one a-piece, all round.']

query: What prize did Alice receive?
expected_answer: The Dodo presented Alice with a thimble as her prize.
citations:
['“Only a thimble,” said Alice sadly.

“Hand it over here,” said the Dodo.

Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly
presented the thimble, saying “We beg your acceptance of this elegant
thimble;” and, when it had finished this short speech, they all
cheered.']

query: What is the Mouse's tale about?
expected_answer: The Mouse's tale is a poem about Fury, who acts as judge and jury, condemning a mouse to death.
citations:
['“Mine is a long and a sad tale!” said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and
sighing.

“It _is_ a long tail, certainly,” said Alice, looking down with wonder
at the Mouse’s tail; “but why do you call it sad?” And she kept on
puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the
tale was something like this:—

         “Fury said to a mouse, That he met in the house, ‘Let us both
         go to law: _I_ will prosecute _you_.—Come, I’ll take no
         denial; We must have a trial: For really this morning I’ve
         nothing to do.’ Said the mouse to the cur, ‘Such a trial, dear
         sir, With no jury or judge, would be wasting our breath.’
         ‘I’ll be judge, I’ll be jury,’ Said cunning old Fury: ‘I’ll
         try the whole cause, and condemn you to death.’”']

query: What are Dinah's characteristics?
expected_answer: Dinah is Alice's cat, and she is very good at catching mice and birds.
citations:
['Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet:
“Dinah’s our cat. And she’s such a capital one for catching mice you
can’t think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why,
she’ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!”']

query: Who did the White Rabbit mistake Alice for?
expected_answer: Alice was mistaken for Mary Ann, the White Rabbit's housemaid.
citations:
['She went in without
knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the
real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the
fan and gloves.']

query: What did Alice find in the White Rabbit's house?
expected_answer: Alice found a fan and several pairs of tiny white kid gloves in a tidy little room.
citations:
['By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table
in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three
pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the
gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a
little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label
this time with the words “DRINK ME,” but nevertheless she uncorked it
and put it to her lips.']

query: What did Alice do when she grew too big for the room?
expected_answer: Alice grew so large that she had to put one arm out of the window and one foot up the chimney.
citations: ['Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out\nof the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself “Now I\ncan do no more, whatever happens. What _will_ become of me?”']

query: What was Pat doing when the Rabbit called him?
expected_answer: Pat was digging for apples.
citations: ['Next came an angry voice—the Rabbit’s—“Pat! Pat! Where are you?” And\nthen a voice she had never heard before, “Sure then I’m here! Digging\nfor apples, yer honour!”']

query: What kind of animal is Bill?
expected_answer: Bill is a lizard.
citations: ['The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle.']

query: What did Alice find on the mushroom?
expected_answer: Alice found a large blue caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom, smoking a long hookah.
citations:
['There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as
herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and
behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what
was on the top of it.

She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the
mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large blue
caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly
smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of
anything else.']

query: What poem did the Caterpillar ask Alice to recite?
expected_answer: The Caterpillar asked Alice to repeat "You are old, Father William."
citations:
['“Repeat, ‘_You are old, Father William_,’” said the Caterpillar.

Alice folded her hands, and began:—

“You are old, Father William,” the young man said,
    “And your hair has become very white;
And yet you incessantly stand on your head—
    Do you think, at your age, it is right?”']

query: What advice did the Caterpillar give Alice about the mushroom?
expected_answer: The Caterpillar told Alice that one side of the mushroom would make her grow taller, and the other side would make her grow shorter.
citations:
['“One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you
grow shorter.”

“One side of _what?_ The other side of _what?_” thought Alice to
herself.

“Of the mushroom,” said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it
aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.']

query: How did Alice return to her normal size?
expected_answer: Alice used the pieces of mushroom to return to her usual height.
citations:
['Alice crouched down among the trees as well
as she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches,
and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it. After a while
she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands,
and she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at
the other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter, until
she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.']

query: What kind of footmen did Alice encounter at the house?
expected_answer: Alice saw a Fish-Footman and a Frog-Footman.
citations:
['For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what
to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the
wood—(she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery:
otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a
fish)—and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles. It was opened by
another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a
frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled
all over their heads.']

query: What message did the Fish-Footman deliver?
expected_answer: The Fish-Footman delivered an invitation from the Queen for the Duchess to play croquet.
citations:
['The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter,
nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other,
saying, in a solemn tone, “For the Duchess. An invitation from the
Queen to play croquet.” The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn
tone, only changing the order of the words a little, “From the Queen.
An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.”']

query: What did Alice see when she entered the house?
expected_answer: Alice entered a kitchen full of smoke, where the Duchess was nursing a baby and the cook was stirring soup.
citations:
['The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from
one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool
in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire,
stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.']

query: Why does the cat grin?
expected_answer: The cat grins because it is a Cheshire cat.
citations:
['The only things in the kitchen
that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting
on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.

“Please would you tell me,” said Alice, a little timidly, for she was
not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, “why
your cat grins like that?”

“It’s a Cheshire cat,” said the Duchess, “and that’s why. Pig!”']

query: What was the lullaby the Duchess sang?
expected_answer: The Duchess sang a lullaby that included the lines: "Speak roughly to your little boy, And beat him when he sneezes: He only does it to annoy, Because he knows it teases."
citations:
['“Speak roughly to your little boy,
    And beat him when he sneezes:
He only does it to annoy,
Because he knows it teases.”']

query: What happened to the baby the Duchess was nursing?
expected_answer: The baby turned into a pig.
citations:
['There could be no doubt that it had
a _very_ turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also
its eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did
not like the look of the thing at all. “But perhaps it was only
sobbing,” she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there
were any tears.

No, there were no tears. “If you’re going to turn into a pig, my dear,”
said Alice, seriously, “I’ll have nothing more to do with you. Mind
now!” The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible
to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.

Alice was just beginning to think to herself, “Now, what am I to do
with this creature when I get it home?” when it grunted again, so
violently, that she looked down into its face in some alarm. This time
there could be _no_ mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than
a pig, and she felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it
further.']

query: Who lives in the direction the Cheshire Cat points?
expected_answer: The Hatter and the March Hare live in the area.
citations: ['“In _that_ direction,” the Cat said, waving its right paw round, “lives\na Hatter: and in _that_ direction,” waving the other paw, “lives a\nMarch Hare. Visit either you like: they’re both mad.”']

query: How does the Cheshire Cat prove it's mad?
expected_answer: The Cat claims to be mad because it growls when pleased and wags its tail when angry, which is the opposite of a dog's behavior.
citations:
['“To begin with,” said the Cat, “a dog’s not mad. You grant that?”

“I suppose so,” said Alice.

“Well, then,” the Cat went on, “you see, a dog growls when it’s angry,
and wags its tail when it’s pleased. Now _I_ growl when I’m pleased,
and wag my tail when I’m angry. Therefore I’m mad.”']

query: How did the Cheshire Cat vanish?
expected_answer: The Cheshire Cat vanished slowly, starting with its tail and ending with its grin, which lingered after the rest of its body was gone.
citations: ['“All right,” said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly,\nbeginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which\nremained some time after the rest of it had gone.']

query: Who was at the Mad Tea-Party?
expected_answer: The March Hare, the Hatter, and a Dormouse were having a tea party.
citations:
['There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the
March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting
between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a
cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head.']

query: What riddle did the Hatter ask?
expected_answer: The Hatter asked, "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?"
citations: ['“Why is a raven like a writing-desk?”']

query: What song did the Hatter sing at the Queen of Hearts' concert?
expected_answer: The Hatter sang "Twinkle, twinkle, little bat! How I wonder what you’re at!" at a concert given by the Queen of Hearts.
citations:
['The Hatter shook his head mournfully. “Not I!” he replied. “We
quarrelled last March—just before _he_ went mad, you know—” (pointing
with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) “—it was at the great concert
given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing

‘Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
How I wonder what you’re at!’']

query: Why is it always tea-time for the Hatter and his friends?
expected_answer: It's always tea-time because the Hatter and Time had a quarrel, and now Time won't do anything the Hatter asks, so it's perpetually six o'clock.
citations:
['“And ever since that,” the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, “he won’t
do a thing I ask! It’s always six o’clock now.”

A bright idea came into Alice’s head. “Is that the reason so many
tea-things are put out here?” she asked.

“Yes, that’s it,” said the Hatter with a sigh: “it’s always tea-time,
and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles.”']

query: What was the Dormouse's story about?
expected_answer: The Dormouse's story is about three little sisters named Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie who lived at the bottom of a well.
citations: ['“Once upon a time there were three little sisters,” the Dormouse began\nin a great hurry; “and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and\nthey lived at the bottom of a well—”']

query: What did the three sisters live on?
expected_answer: The three sisters lived on treacle.
citations: ['“They lived on treacle,” said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or\ntwo.']

query: Why did the three sisters live at the bottom of a well?
expected_answer: They lived at the bottom of a "treacle-well."
citations: ['“It was a treacle-well.”']

query: What did the three sisters draw?
expected_answer: The three sisters drew treacle.
citations:
['“And so these three little sisters—they were learning to draw,
you know—”

“What did they draw?” said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.

“Treacle,” said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.']

query: What did the Dormouse say the sisters drew?
expected_answer: The Dormouse said they drew things that begin with an M, such as mouse-traps, the moon, memory, and muchness.
citations:
['“—that begins with an M, such as
mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say
things are “much of a muchness”—did you ever see such a thing as a
drawing of a muchness?”']

query: What were the gardeners doing to the roses?
expected_answer: Three gardeners were painting white roses red.
citations: ['A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses\ngrowing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily\npainting them red.']

query: Describe the procession of the Queen of Hearts.
expected_answer: The procession included ten soldiers, ten courtiers, ten royal children, guests (mostly Kings and Queens, including the White Rabbit), the Knave of Hearts, and finally, the King and Queen of Hearts.
citations:
['First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the
three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the
corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with
diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did. After these came
the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came
jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all
ornamented with hearts. Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens,
and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a
hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went
by without noticing her. Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying
the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this
grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.']

query: What is the Queen of Hearts' favorite phrase?
expected_answer: The Queen of Hearts frequently shouts "Off with her head!" or "Off with his head!"
citations: ['“Off with her head! Off—”']

query: How is croquet played in the Queen's garden?
expected_answer: The croquet game used live hedgehogs as balls, live flamingoes as mallets, and soldiers doubled up to form arches.
citations:
['Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground
in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live
hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double
themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.']

query: Why was the Duchess sentenced to execution?
expected_answer: The Duchess was sentenced to execution for boxing the Queen's ears.
citations:
['“She boxed the Queen’s ears—” the Rabbit began. Alice gave a little
scream of laughter. “Oh, hush!” the Rabbit whispered in a frightened
tone. “The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the
Queen said—”']

query: What is a Mock Turtle?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle is the creature from which Mock Turtle Soup is made.
citations: ['“It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.']

query: What did the Mock Turtle reveal about his past?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle revealed that he was once a real Turtle.
citations: ['“Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real\nTurtle.”']

query: Why was their schoolmaster called Tortoise?
expected_answer: They called their master Tortoise because he taught them.
citations: ['“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle\nangrily: “really you are very dull!”']

query: What subjects did the Mock Turtle learn in school?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle learned Reeling and Writhing, and branches of Arithmetic including Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.
citations: ['“Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle\nreplied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition,\nDistraction, Uglification, and Derision.”']

query: What other subjects did the Mock Turtle mention learning?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle also learned Mystery (ancient and modern), Seaography, Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.
citations:
['“—Mystery, ancient and modern, with
Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel,
that used to come once a week: _he_ taught us Drawling, Stretching, and
Fainting in Coils.”']

query: Why were the subjects called 'lessons'?
expected_answer: Lessons were called "lessons" because the number of hours spent on them lessened each day.
citations:
['“Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so
on.”

“What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.

“That’s the reason they’re called lessons,” the Gryphon remarked:
“because they lessen from day to day.”']

query: Describe the steps of the Lobster Quadrille.
expected_answer: The Lobster Quadrille involves forming two lines with lobsters as partners, advancing, changing lobsters, retiring, throwing lobsters into the sea, swimming after them, turning somersaults, changing lobsters again, and returning to land.
citations:
['“Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the
sea-shore—”

“Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on;
then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”

“_That_ generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon.

“—you advance twice—”

“Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.

“Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”

“—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.

“Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”

“The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.

“—as far out to sea as you can—”

“Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.

“Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly
about.

“Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.

“Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock
Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had
been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very
sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.']

query: What is the song about the whiting about?
expected_answer: The song is about a whiting asking a snail to walk faster to join the Lobster Quadrille, as a porpoise is behind them.
citations:
['“Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
“There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?']

query: Why is it called a whiting?
expected_answer: The Gryphon said a whiting "does the boots and shoes," meaning it makes them shiny.
citations: ['“_It does the boots and shoes_,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.']

query: What are boots and shoes made of under the sea?
expected_answer: Boots and shoes under the sea are made of soles and eels.
citations: ['“Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently:\n“any shrimp could have told you that.”']

query: Why was the Mock Turtle offended by Alice's question about "porpoise"?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle was offended when Alice corrected his use of "porpoise" instead of "purpose."
citations: ['“I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And\nthe Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of _your_ adventures.”']

query: What poem did Alice recite about a Lobster?
expected_answer: Alice recited a poem that began: "’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare, “You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”"
citations:
['“’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
“You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”']

query: What was the next verse Alice recited?
expected_answer: Alice recited a poem about an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie.
citations: ['“I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,\nHow the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”']

query: What song did the Mock Turtle sing?
expected_answer: The Mock Turtle sang a song called "Turtle Soup," which describes "Beautiful Soup, so rich and green."
citations:
['“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beautiful Soup!']

query: What was the trial about?
expected_answer: The trial was for the Knave of Hearts, who was accused of stealing the tarts.
citations:
['The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they
arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little
birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was
standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard
him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one
hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the
court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so
good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d
get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!”']

query: Who was the judge at the trial?
expected_answer: The King was the judge.
citations: ['The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the\nwig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he\ndid not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.']

query: What were the jurors writing on their slates?
expected_answer: The jurors were writing down their names so they wouldn't forget them before the trial ended.
citations:
['The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are
they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything
to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”

“They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply,
“for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”']

query: What was the accusation read by the White Rabbit?
expected_answer: The accusation was that the Knave of Hearts stole the tarts made by the Queen of Hearts.
citations:
['“The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
    All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
    And took them quite away!”']

query: Who was the first witness called?
expected_answer: The first witness was the Hatter.
citations:
['The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand
and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your
Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished
my tea when I was sent for.”']

query: What dates did the Hatter, March Hare, and Dormouse give for when the Hatter began his tea?
expected_answer: The Hatter said he began his tea on the fourteenth of March, the March Hare said the fifteenth, and the Dormouse said the sixteenth.
citations:
['“Fourteenth of March, I _think_ it
was,” he said.

“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.

“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.']

query: Why did the Hatter say his hat wasn't his own?
expected_answer: The Hatter explained that he keeps hats to sell, as he is a hatter and doesn't own any himself.
citations: ['“I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none\nof my own. I’m a hatter.”']

query: How were the guinea-pigs suppressed in the court?
expected_answer: The guinea-pigs were suppressed by being slipped headfirst into a canvas bag, which was then tied up and sat upon by the officers.
citations:
['Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by
the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just
explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied
up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig,
head first, and then sat upon it.)']

query: Who was the next witness?
expected_answer: The next witness was the Duchess's cook.
citations: ['The next witness was the Duchess’s cook. She carried the pepper-box in\nher hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the\ncourt, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.']

query: What did the cook say tarts are made of?
expected_answer: The cook said tarts are made mostly of pepper.
citations: ['“Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.']

query: What was Rule Forty-two?
expected_answer: The King read out Rule Forty-two: "All persons more than a mile high to leave the court."
citations: ['“Rule\nForty-two. _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_.”']

query: What was the paper found by the White Rabbit?
expected_answer: The paper was a set of verses, not a letter, and it wasn't directed to anyone.
citations:
['“I haven’t opened it yet,” said the White Rabbit, “but it seems to be a
letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.”

“It must have been that,” said the King, “unless it was written to
nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.”

“Who is it directed to?” said one of the jurymen.

“It isn’t directed at all,” said the White Rabbit; “in fact, there’s
nothing written on the _outside_.” He unfolded the paper as he spoke,
and added “It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.”']

query: What were the verses about?
expected_answer: The verses describe a secret affair involving "her," "him," and "you," with mentions of good character, inability to swim, and the giving and returning of items.
citations:
['“They told me you had been to her,
    And mentioned me to him:
She gave me a good character,
    But said I could not swim.

He sent them word I had not gone
    (We know it to be true):
If she should push the matter on,
    What would become of you?

I gave her one, they gave him two,
    You gave us three or more;
They all returned from him to you,
    Though they were mine before.

If I or she should chance to be
    Involved in this affair,
He trusts to you to set them free,
    Exactly as we were.

My notion was that you had been
    (Before she had this fit)
An obstacle that came between
    Him, and ourselves, and it.

Don’t let him know she liked them best,
    For this must ever be
A secret, kept from all the rest,
    Between yourself and me.”']

query: What was the Queen's unusual demand regarding the trial?
expected_answer: The Queen wanted the sentence to be given before the verdict.
citations: ['“No, no!” said the Queen. “Sentence first—verdict afterwards.”']

query: What did Alice call the King and Queen?
expected_answer: Alice called the King and Queen "nothing but a pack of cards."
citations: ['“Who cares for you?” said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by\nthis time.) “You’re nothing but a pack of cards!”']

query: How did Alice's adventure end?
expected_answer: Alice woke up lying on the bank with her head in her sister's lap.
citations:
['At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon
her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and
tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her
head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead
leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.']

query: What did Alice tell her sister after waking up?
expected_answer: Alice told her sister about her curious dream.
citations:
['“Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!” said Alice, and she told her
sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange
Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she
had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, “It _was_ a curious
dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.”']

query: What did Alice's sister dream about Alice's future?
expected_answer: Alice's sister dreamed of Alice as a grown woman, retaining her childhood heart, telling stories to other children, and sharing their joys and sorrows.
citations:
['Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers
would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would
keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her
childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children,
and make _their_ eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale,
perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she
would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all
their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer
days.']
